thread.title: Over 50s want to work longer, report finds
thread.title_full: Over 50s want to work longer, report finds | afr.com

author: Ruth Liew
title: Over 50s want to work longer, report finds
text:
FSC chief executive Sally Loane said: "The difference this year is that we have the emergence of Gen X-ers who are now entering the older work force, and they're bringing in new attitudes to the work force as well." Sahlan Hayes Share on twitter by Ruth Liew Three out of four people over 50 are willing to stay in the workforce longer to boost their retirement savings, reflecting workers' increasing concerns about their financial security.
Around 72 per cent of older people are happy to stay in the workforce longer, 61 per cent cite "financial security" as the major reason for their decision, research from the Commonwealth Bank and Financial Services Council finds.
"There is a growing recognition of how much money you do need to retire on – by far the majority [of people who want to work longer] say that it's because of some sort of financial reason," said CBA's general manager retirement Nicolette Rubinsztein.
"Almost 40 per cent of them point to a more personal fulfilment and enjoyment for wanting to stay in the workforce."
The survey found 66 per cent of older workers were "satisfied" they had sufficient funds put aside to retire, which is an improvement from 2012 when confidence levels were below 50 per cent.
FSC chief executive Sally Loane said sustaining a comfortable retirement remained top of mind for older people.
"The difference this year is that we have the emergence of Gen X-ers who are now entering the older work force, and they're bringing in new attitudes to the work force as well," Ms Loane said.
"The good news is that age discrimination towards older workers has more than halved to 13 per cent in this year's survey compared to 28 per cent in 2012," she said.
 The average person would like to work an additional six years beyond the current retirement age of 60, with 27 per cent indicating they would like to work for 10 years or more.
Pump $200 billion The findings, based on a survey of 500 people, comes after the federal government's Intergenerational Report found people will have to work longer over the next 40 years.
Each year, those who work beyond retirement age pump $200 billion into the retirement system. The $1.85 trillion superannuation industry is expected to grow by $1 trillion over the next 10 years, as super assets make up the biggest component of retirees' assets outside of their own home.
The Intergenerational Report found work participation rates of those aged 65 and older will climb from the current 12.9 per cent in 2014-15, to 17.3 per cent by 2055.
Nearly 50 per cent of respondents say they experienced no barriers to continuing to work. Those who faced roadblocks in finding jobs cited health reasons, ageism or discrimination against older workers and keeping up with technological change as being some of their concerns.
"Flexible working arrangements have played an important role in encouraging older workers to stay in the workforce – allowing them to maintain a healthy work life balance and prove the freedom and financial means to attend to their personal and family needs," Ms Rubinsztein said.
